ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Kartikeya
Kartikeya Singh
Kartikeya Singh
K. Singh
Kartikeya
Kartikeya Singh
Kartikeya Singh
Kartikeya Sigh
Kartikeya Singh

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I wish that Professor Lee would have lectured more. While I understand the value of student presentations, there should be a better balance. Professor Lee has so much valuable experience to share and I would have preferred to hear that rather than presentations by classmates during EVERY class.

This is a great course, but it needs more structure. The internship opportunity that it provides at the UN is invaluable. The trip to the UNFCCC conference was great, but didn't seem to be well planned.Professor Lee has an excellent knowledge of the subject matter, but the class should have more structure. It also seemed as though he had favorites in class, and he would assign more work to some students than he did to others. More structure and a syllabus would help to alleviate this type of problem.The TA sometimes didn't seem to know what was going on with the assignments, but I think that was because Professor Lee didn't tell him, and would sometimes send assignments out two days, or the night before class. This type of thing does help you get used to the UN process, but doesn't help you manage your work load.
Prof and TA could have done a better job providing students with a better understanding of the procedural aspects of the UN and UNFCCC.
The internships at the UN that are part of this course are a very valuable experience for students interested in learning how the UN works as well as in climate change negotiations.
Working with a delegation at the UNFCCC, and the internship at the UN.

The opportunity to do an internship with a permanent mission to the UN, as well as go for the UNFCCC Conference of Parties with a country delegation. These are invaluable opportunities that allow an insight into the international processes and mechanisms that facilitate cooperation or communications between countries.
Conference attendance.
The chance to work in UN and the chance to go to Cancun for the COP 16.
The opportunity to work as part of a delegation in the climate change negotiations as well as working as an intern for a mission at the UN.

The best thing about this course is the ability to engage on international environmental diplomacy on the issues that you care about most. Ad hoc projects and assignments that built on one another drove us to research and deliver presentations and reports to the class, which forced us to really understand the material.Of course, the experience to intern at a country mission to the United Nations was incredible, and an amazing experience to see how the international process works up close.
The opportunity to learn from the United Nations

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More structure, and an equal distribution of work. There also seemed to be a lot of back room deals regarding the classes trip to Grenada that is happening at the end of the semester.

I suppose the class will benefit from further clarity regarding the work and assignments entailed by enrolling in the class. It seemed like many developed a siege mentality as the class went on, and while keeping us always ready is good, it disrupts long-term planning with other commitments.

Some students didn't have thematic topics to follow until late in the course or at all. Perhaps this can be better incorporated into the application process, since it is more beneficial for the student as well as others in class who can learn more from someone who is genuinely interested in a given topic than one who has a more general level of interest.

To organize the course more logically and follow a clear syllabus. Let the students know what will be included in the course. To distribute the courseload, like the presentation more evenly among all the students.
The instructor could improve the organization and structure of the course, lectures and be more clear about what is expected from the assignments.
Although the ad hoc assignments kept us on our toes, I think that a better sense of direction for where the class is leading, and a more graceful flow between meetings would be a great improvement.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The Instructor relied a lot on the TA, and the TA had a, "just deal with it," attitude.
The TA was very helpful for clarifying concepts or providing information when approached.
The instructor and the TA were both available to answer questions and discuss material and questions from the course.
When I did contact both Professor Lee and Kartikeya, they were helpful and generally prompt with their responses.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: After graduation, I will be returning for eventual work in the civil service in my country, and I feel it is necessary to know how national policies are influenced or coordinated with international efforts, especially with regards to environmental issues. The class, with its internship opportunities, allowed me the chance in fulfilling that.
This course expanded my overall scope of interests by the end, which resulted in me finding unexpected interests.

I wanted to stay current with international climate negotiations to understand better the context for carbon pricing, sustainable transport, and other environmental-business interactions will have in the coming years.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get exposure on environmental policy issues from a global perspective rather than a domestic/developed country perspective.

I wanted to stay current withinternational climate negotiations to understand better the context for carbon pricing, sustainable transport, and other environmental-business interactions will have in the coming years. Also, the experience to intern at the United Nations was something for which I had to apply.
To add to my portfolio of 'policy'; but more especially, to learn the 'negotiation' process.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, it definitely did.
Exceeded them.

Kind of. I got to know more about carbon finance that I expected, and was able to participate more fully in the Cancun conference that I ever thought I would. However, the disorder during the semester was a little bit of a let down. I know that these things are hard to arrange, but I wish the UN internships had started earlier in the semester.
Yes it did

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, definitely.
More than expected.
No, but I did get wonderful experiences and a good opportunity to learn more about the international climate negotiating framework.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantages were getting a new friend, and exploring a sector in relative depth. Disadvantages were scheduling time, and a proper proportion of the work for each of us to do.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: be prepared for the unpredictable nature of the course

Be prepared to do work/research and produce presentations or briefs within a few days notice. It is a good skill to develop through out the class, and also for working life later. Be open to topics that you have no experience in, and listen to the advice and guidance of the professor, because most of the time, he is right and knows what he is talking about!
Pick a interest early on and follow it. Concentrate on both process and substance of topic of interest. Don't write and release or say something that you haven't fully vetted.
Accept the disorder and talk to Professor Lee early and often about starting the internship.
